Getting sufficient sleep may even save others’ lives, the agency points out, as rested drivers <https://fortune.com/2018/02/08/drowsy-driving-cause-crashes/> are less likely to cause motor vehicle crashes resulting in injury and death.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/bad-sleep-habits/\n\nSource 2:\nSleep 101\n\nDoctors and scientists have long been touting the benefits of sleep for the brain and body. It’s true—sleep is an essential part of maintaining overall well-being. When you are well rested, your mood improves, your stress levels decrease, and you tend to feel more productive. \n\nBeyond <https://fortune.com/company/overstock-com/> quantity of sleep, research has shown that the quality <https://fortune.com/well/2023/03/03/sleep-diet-exercise-goals/> of your sleep matters too. While current guidelines recommend adults get between seven and nine hours <https://www.cdc.gov/sleep/about_sleep/how_much_sleep.html> of sleep, over a third of Americans do not meet the minimum. It’s too easy to give in to the over-stimulating activities at your fingertips—hello, TikTok—instead of turning the lights off. Minutes scrolling on social media before bed turn into hours, and screens have made it harder to shut off the brain and prepare for a good night’s rest—ever heard of revenge bedtime procrastination <https://fortune.com/well/2022/08/25/how-to-stop-revenge-bedtime-procrastination/>?\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/28/guide-to-better-sleep/\n\nSource 2:\nGetting little sleep is associated with an increased risk of chronic health conditions like heart disease and stroke. Sleeping less puts people at risk of mental health problems like anxiety and depression. One study found older adults who get five or fewer hours <https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/19/sleeping-five-hours-or-less-can-raise-your-risk-for-multiple-conditions-including-cancer-and-diabetes/> of sleep are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions. So, improving sleep can, in turn, improve our lives. Even following certain sleep habits <https://fortune.com/well/2023/02/23/healthy-sleep-habits-for-aging/> can increase your life expectancy, per one study. \n\nSleep basics\n\nHow much sleep do I need? \n\nAccording to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), adults need at least seven hours of sleep. For those 65 and older, the CDC recommends between seven and eight hours of sleep each night. \n\nWhy is it harder to sleep for older adults?\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/28/guide-to-better-sleep/\n\nSource 3:\nKey takeaways\n\n * Seven to nine hours of sleep per night can help with health and fitness goals \n * Quality of sleep determined by six factors: regularity, satisfaction, alertness, timing, efficiency and duration \n * Sleep is closely tied to cardiovascular health \nBetter sleep may be the solution for everything from adding years to your life <https://fortune.com/well/2023/02/23/healthy-sleep-habits-for-aging/> to better health and wellness. According to research presented at the American Heart Association’s Epidemiology, Prevention, Lifestyle & Cardiometabolic Health Scientific Sessions 2023 <https://professional.heart.org/en/meetings/epi-lifestyle> in Boston earlier this week, people who reported regular, uninterrupted sleep were better at sticking to exercise and diet plans while trying to lose weight.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/03/03/sleep-diet-exercise-goals/\n\nSource 3:\n“Focusing on obtaining good sleep—seven to nine hours at night with a regular wake time along with waking refreshed and being alert throughout the day—may be an important behavior that helps people stick with their physical activity and dietary modification goals,” said Christopher E. Kline, Ph.D., an associate professor in the department of health and human development at the University of Pittsburgh, in a press release <https://newsroom.heart.org/news/a-good-nights-sleep-may-make-it-easier-to-stick-to-exercise-and-diet-goals-study-found?preview=a943> about the study. “A previous study of ours reported that better sleep health was associated with a significantly greater loss of body weight and fat among participants in a year-long, behavioral weight loss program <https://fortune.com/recommends/health/best-weight-loss-program/>.”\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/03/03/sleep-diet-exercise-goals/\n\nSource 4:\n“Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep their benefits are greatly reduced,” Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director, Indiana Sleep Center, expert at SleepFoundation.org <https://www.sleepfoundation.org/>, and coauthor of Sleep to Heal: 7 Simple Steps to Better Sleep <https://www.amazon.com/Sleep-Heal-Refresh-Restore-Revitalize/dp/1630062340/ref=sr_1_1?crid=222HN5DUONGAM&keywords=sleep+to+heal&qid=1677545988&sprefix=sleep+to+heal%2Caps%2C123&sr=8-1>, previously told Fortune. “Sleep is important for metabolic health, immune health, muscle repair, optimal brain function, and mental health. Optimal sleep not only adds years to your life, but life to your years.”\n\nThis story was originally featured on Fortune.com <https://fortune.com/well/2023/07/30/how-to-fall-back-asleep/>\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/07/30/how-to-fall-back-asleep/\n\nSource 5:\n“Everyone has a different kind of job with different kinds of demands, and a lack of sleep can present many challenges for us, as far as emotion regulation [and] our ability to focus,” Snowden says. “These are big capacities that we need to get through the day, to be productive and do our jobs well, and to be present for our loved ones.”\n\nMore than a third of American adults do not get the recommended minimum of seven hours of sleep a night as it is, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) <https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/p0215-enough-sleep.html>. Prioritizing sleep means investing in a quality mattress <https://fortune.com/recommends/health/best-mattress/> having good sleep hygiene <https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/19/sleeping-five-hours-or-less-can-raise-your-risk-for-multiple-conditions-including-cancer-and-diabetes/>, including waking up around the same time each day, limiting screens before bed, not consuming alcohol or caffeine in the evenings, and having a wind-down routine.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/waking-up-at-5-a-m-every-day-could-improve-your-life-heres-how-to-make-it-work-for-you/\n\nSource 6:\nWhy does getting enough sleep matter?\n\nHow you feel when you’re awake partially depends on what happens when you’re sleeping, according to the CDC <https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/sleep/why-sleep-important>. When you sleep, your body performs work that supports healthy brain function and physical health. And for children and teens, getting enough sleep aids healthy growth and development.\n\nAdequate sleep supports the following body functions, the CDC says:\n\n * Heart and circulatory system: People who don’t sleep enough or wake up often may have a higher risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and/or stroke.\n\n * Metabolism: Not getting enough quality shut eye may lead to insulin resistance, increased eating (especially of unhealthy foods), and decreased physical activity, all of which contribute to obesity, which carries its own health risks.\n\n * Immune systems: A particular type of immune cell works harder when you sleep. That’s why those who don’t get enough sleep may get sick more often.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/should-you-go-back-to-sleep-if-you-wake-up-before-your-alarm/\n\nSource 6:\n* Cognition: Sleep aids in learning and forming long-term memories. Those who don’t get enough high-quality sleep might have problems focusing and thinking clearly. \nCopious medical studies support the need for adequate sleep, and quality sleep. Cases in point:\n\n * People who get less than five hours of sleep each night are more than three times more likely to have a stroke than those who get the recommended seven hours, according to a study published in April in the journal Neurology <https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/05/bad-sleep-increased-stroke-risk-tips-better-sleep-apnea-snoring-snorting/>.\n\n * People who struggle to fall asleep and stay asleep may also be at a greater risk of a stroke, according to research published in June in the journal Neurology <https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/07/insomnia-symptoms-trouble-sleeping-increased-stroke-risk/>.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/should-you-go-back-to-sleep-if-you-wake-up-before-your-alarm/\n\nSource 7:\n2. Get enough sleep and exercise\n\nBoth Bennett and Azzaro underscore the importance of consistent good sleep <https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/28/guide-to-better-sleep/> and exercise <https://fortune.com/well/2023/08/12/how-much-exercise-do-i-need-each-week-does-walking-count/>.\n\nStudies <https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6984036/> have shown that poor sleep quality can lead to higher stress levels, making it more difficult to handle daily stressors and regulate emotions.\nAim for seven to eight hours a night, says Bennett. Sleep habits <https://fortune.com/well/article/should-you-go-back-to-sleep-if-you-wake-up-before-your-alarm/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks> are also important. These include going to bed and waking at the same time each day; sleeping in a quiet, dark, cool room <https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/02/best-temperature-for-sleep/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks>; removing devices from the bedroom and taking a break from them before bedtime; and avoiding caffeine and alcohol before bed, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/how-to-lower-cortisol/\n\nSource 8:\nAdults need between seven and nine hours of sleep at night to feel well-rested, so moving up your bedtime by just 15 minutes and eventually 30 may be beneficial and help you get there. It’s essential because the quality of sleep depends on aligning your bedtime and wake time with the body’s natural clock, and the deepest sleep may happen between 10 p.m. and 2 a.m <https://fortune.com/well/article/bed-9-p-m-every-night-health-benefits/>. Sleep experts have previously told Fortune <https://fortune.com/well/article/bed-9-p-m-every-night-health-benefits/> that the best sleep habits stick when done in small increments over time <https://fortune.com/well/2024/02/14/atomic-habits-james-clear-app-goals-atoms/>. Dr. Raj Dasgupta, an internal medicine doctor and sleep scientist, has also touted a 30- to 60-minute wind-down routine before bed to calm the nervous system and set yourself up for success.\n\nWhether you choose one or all of these adjustments, prioritize what makes you feel better and integrate it into your day more routinely.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/micro-changes-feel-better-today/\n\nSource 9:\n4. Magnesium for relaxation \n\nIf counting sheep doesn’t send you into a blissful slumber <https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/28/guide-to-better-sleep/>, magnesium might. This supplement reduces the stress hormone cortisol <https://fortune.com/well/article/cortisol-how-to-lower-stress-hormone/>, potentially resulting in more relaxed mind and muscles. It activates your body’s natural melatonin and promotes the production of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), a neurotransmitter that helps you fall asleep quicker without feeling groggy in the morning. Studies have also shown that this supplement may help regulate  <https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35184264/>your sleep schedule. \n\nRemember that results take time, advises Mirhom; as with most supplements, magnesium <https://fortune.com/recommends/health/best-magensium-supplement/> must be taken consistently over time to be effective. Experts recommend taking no more than 350 milligrams of the supplement per day to avoid side effects like diarrhea, nausea, and cramping.\n\n5. Probiotics for brain health\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/best-supplements-for-mental-health/'}

That is, never cite a source using format 'Source n', but rather use '[n]'.\n\nHere is an example of how to cite sources:\n\nSource 1:\nThe sky is red in the evening and blue in the morning.\n\nSource 2:\nWater is wet when the sky is red.\n\nQuestion: When is water wet?\n\nAnswer with citations: Water will be wet when the sky is red [2], which occurs in the evening [1].\n\nOkay, now your set of sources for answering the user query follow:\n\n{context_str}\nOnly make statements you can support from the sources provided or information provided by the human. Getting sufficient sleep may even save others’ lives, the agency points out, as rested drivers <https://fortune.com/2018/02/08/drowsy-driving-cause-crashes/> are less likely to cause motor vehicle crashes resulting in injury and death.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/bad-sleep-habits/\n\nSource 2:\nSleep 101\n\nDoctors and scientists have long been touting the benefits of sleep for the brain and body. It’s true—sleep is an essential part of maintaining overall well-being. When you are well rested, your mood improves, your stress levels decrease, and you tend to feel more productive. \n\nBeyond <https://fortune.com/company/overstock-com/> quantity of sleep, research has shown that the quality <https://fortune.com/well/2023/03/03/sleep-diet-exercise-goals/> of your sleep matters too. While current guidelines recommend adults get between seven and nine hours <https://www.cdc.gov/sleep/about_sleep/how_much_sleep.html> of sleep, over a third of Americans do not meet the minimum. It’s too easy to give in to the over-stimulating activities at your fingertips—hello, TikTok—instead of turning the lights off. Minutes scrolling on social media before bed turn into hours, and screens have made it harder to shut off the brain and prepare for a good night’s rest—ever heard of revenge bedtime procrastination <https://fortune.com/well/2022/08/25/how-to-stop-revenge-bedtime-procrastination/>?\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/28/guide-to-better-sleep/\n\nSource 2:\nGetting little sleep is associated with an increased risk of chronic health conditions like heart disease and stroke. Sleeping less puts people at risk of mental health problems like anxiety and depression. One study found older adults who get five or fewer hours <https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/19/sleeping-five-hours-or-less-can-raise-your-risk-for-multiple-conditions-including-cancer-and-diabetes/> of sleep are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions. So, improving sleep can, in turn, improve our lives. Even following certain sleep habits <https://fortune.com/well/2023/02/23/healthy-sleep-habits-for-aging/> can increase your life expectancy, per one study. \n\nSleep basics\n\nHow much sleep do I need? \n\nAccording to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), adults need at least seven hours of sleep. For those 65 and older, the CDC recommends between seven and eight hours of sleep each night. \n\nWhy is it harder to sleep for older adults?\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/28/guide-to-better-sleep/\n\nSource 3:\nKey takeaways\n\n * Seven to nine hours of sleep per night can help with health and fitness goals \n * Quality of sleep determined by six factors: regularity, satisfaction, alertness, timing, efficiency and duration \n * Sleep is closely tied to cardiovascular health \nBetter sleep may be the solution for everything from adding years to your life <https://fortune.com/well/2023/02/23/healthy-sleep-habits-for-aging/> to better health and wellness. According to research presented at the American Heart Association’s Epidemiology, Prevention, Lifestyle & Cardiometabolic Health Scientific Sessions 2023 <https://professional.heart.org/en/meetings/epi-lifestyle> in Boston earlier this week, people who reported regular, uninterrupted sleep were better at sticking to exercise and diet plans while trying to lose weight.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/03/03/sleep-diet-exercise-goals/\n\nSource 3:\n“Focusing on obtaining good sleep—seven to nine hours at night with a regular wake time along with waking refreshed and being alert throughout the day—may be an important behavior that helps people stick with their physical activity and dietary modification goals,” said Christopher E. Kline, Ph.D., an associate professor in the department of health and human development at the University of Pittsburgh, in a press release <https://newsroom.heart.org/news/a-good-nights-sleep-may-make-it-easier-to-stick-to-exercise-and-diet-goals-study-found?preview=a943> about the study. “A previous study of ours reported that better sleep health was associated with a significantly greater loss of body weight and fat among participants in a year-long, behavioral weight loss program <https://fortune.com/recommends/health/best-weight-loss-program/>.”\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/03/03/sleep-diet-exercise-goals/\n\nSource 4:\n“Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep their benefits are greatly reduced,” Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director, Indiana Sleep Center, expert at SleepFoundation.org <https://www.sleepfoundation.org/>, and coauthor of Sleep to Heal: 7 Simple Steps to Better Sleep <https://www.amazon.com/Sleep-Heal-Refresh-Restore-Revitalize/dp/1630062340/ref=sr_1_1?crid=222HN5DUONGAM&keywords=sleep+to+heal&qid=1677545988&sprefix=sleep+to+heal%2Caps%2C123&sr=8-1>, previously told Fortune. “Sleep is important for metabolic health, immune health, muscle repair, optimal brain function, and mental health. Optimal sleep not only adds years to your life, but life to your years.”\n\nThis story was originally featured on Fortune.com <https://fortune.com/well/2023/07/30/how-to-fall-back-asleep/>\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/07/30/how-to-fall-back-asleep/\n\nSource 5:\n“Everyone has a different kind of job with different kinds of demands, and a lack of sleep can present many challenges for us, as far as emotion regulation [and] our ability to focus,” Snowden says. “These are big capacities that we need to get through the day, to be productive and do our jobs well, and to be present for our loved ones.”\n\nMore than a third of American adults do not get the recommended minimum of seven hours of sleep a night as it is, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) <https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2016/p0215-enough-sleep.html>. Prioritizing sleep means investing in a quality mattress <https://fortune.com/recommends/health/best-mattress/> having good sleep hygiene <https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/19/sleeping-five-hours-or-less-can-raise-your-risk-for-multiple-conditions-including-cancer-and-diabetes/>, including waking up around the same time each day, limiting screens before bed, not consuming alcohol or caffeine in the evenings, and having a wind-down routine.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/waking-up-at-5-a-m-every-day-could-improve-your-life-heres-how-to-make-it-work-for-you/\n\nSource 6:\nWhy does getting enough sleep matter?\n\nHow you feel when you’re awake partially depends on what happens when you’re sleeping, according to the CDC <https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/sleep/why-sleep-important>. When you sleep, your body performs work that supports healthy brain function and physical health. And for children and teens, getting enough sleep aids healthy growth and development.\n\nAdequate sleep supports the following body functions, the CDC says:\n\n * Heart and circulatory system: People who don’t sleep enough or wake up often may have a higher risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and/or stroke.\n\n * Metabolism: Not getting enough quality shut eye may lead to insulin resistance, increased eating (especially of unhealthy foods), and decreased physical activity, all of which contribute to obesity, which carries its own health risks.\n\n * Immune systems: A particular type of immune cell works harder when you sleep. That’s why those who don’t get enough sleep may get sick more often.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/should-you-go-back-to-sleep-if-you-wake-up-before-your-alarm/\n\nSource 6:\n* Cognition: Sleep aids in learning and forming long-term memories. Those who don’t get enough high-quality sleep might have problems focusing and thinking clearly. \nCopious medical studies support the need for adequate sleep, and quality sleep. Cases in point:\n\n * People who get less than five hours of sleep each night are more than three times more likely to have a stroke than those who get the recommended seven hours, according to a study published in April in the journal Neurology <https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/05/bad-sleep-increased-stroke-risk-tips-better-sleep-apnea-snoring-snorting/>.\n\n * People who struggle to fall asleep and stay asleep may also be at a greater risk of a stroke, according to research published in June in the journal Neurology <https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/07/insomnia-symptoms-trouble-sleeping-increased-stroke-risk/>.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/should-you-go-back-to-sleep-if-you-wake-up-before-your-alarm/\n\nSource 7:\n2. Get enough sleep and exercise\n\nBoth Bennett and Azzaro underscore the importance of consistent good sleep <https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/28/guide-to-better-sleep/> and exercise <https://fortune.com/well/2023/08/12/how-much-exercise-do-i-need-each-week-does-walking-count/>.\n\nStudies <https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6984036/> have shown that poor sleep quality can lead to higher stress levels, making it more difficult to handle daily stressors and regulate emotions.\nAim for seven to eight hours a night, says Bennett. Sleep habits <https://fortune.com/well/article/should-you-go-back-to-sleep-if-you-wake-up-before-your-alarm/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks> are also important. These include going to bed and waking at the same time each day; sleeping in a quiet, dark, cool room <https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/02/best-temperature-for-sleep/?utm_source=search&utm_medium=suggested_search&utm_campaign=search_link_clicks>; removing devices from the bedroom and taking a break from them before bedtime; and avoiding caffeine and alcohol before bed, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/how-to-lower-cortisol/\n\nSource 8:\nAdults need between seven and nine hours of sleep at night to feel well-rested, so moving up your bedtime by just 15 minutes and eventually 30 may be beneficial and help you get there. It’s essential because the quality of sleep depends on aligning your bedtime and wake time with the body’s natural clock, and the deepest sleep may happen between 10 p.m. and 2 a.m <https://fortune.com/well/article/bed-9-p-m-every-night-health-benefits/>. Sleep experts have previously told Fortune <https://fortune.com/well/article/bed-9-p-m-every-night-health-benefits/> that the best sleep habits stick when done in small increments over time <https://fortune.com/well/2024/02/14/atomic-habits-james-clear-app-goals-atoms/>. Dr. Raj Dasgupta, an internal medicine doctor and sleep scientist, has also touted a 30- to 60-minute wind-down routine before bed to calm the nervous system and set yourself up for success.\n\nWhether you choose one or all of these adjustments, prioritize what makes you feel better and integrate it into your day more routinely.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/micro-changes-feel-better-today/\n\nSource 9:\n4. Magnesium for relaxation \n\nIf counting sheep doesn’t send you into a blissful slumber <https://fortune.com/well/2023/06/28/guide-to-better-sleep/>, magnesium might. This supplement reduces the stress hormone cortisol <https://fortune.com/well/article/cortisol-how-to-lower-stress-hormone/>, potentially resulting in more relaxed mind and muscles. It activates your body’s natural melatonin and promotes the production of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), a neurotransmitter that helps you fall asleep quicker without feeling groggy in the morning. Studies have also shown that this supplement may help regulate  <https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35184264/>your sleep schedule. \n\nRemember that results take time, advises Mirhom; as with most supplements, magnesium <https://fortune.com/recommends/health/best-magensium-supplement/> must be taken consistently over time to be effective. Experts recommend taking no more than 350 milligrams of the supplement per day to avoid side effects like diarrhea, nausea, and cramping.\n\n5. Probiotics for brain health\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/best-supplements-for-mental-health/'}

This supplement reduces the stress hormone cortisol <https://fortune.com/well/article/cortisol-how-to-lower-stress-hormone/>, potentially resulting in more relaxed mind and muscles. It activates your body’s natural melatonin and promotes the production of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), a neurotransmitter that helps you fall asleep quicker without feeling groggy in the morning. Studies have also shown that this supplement may help regulate  <https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35184264/>your sleep schedule. \n\nRemember that results take time, advises Mirhom; as with most supplements, magnesium <https://fortune.com/recommends/health/best-magensium-supplement/> must be taken consistently over time to be effective. Experts recommend taking no more than 350 milligrams of the supplement per day to avoid side effects like diarrhea, nausea, and cramping.\n\n5. Probiotics for brain health\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/article/best-supplements-for-mental-health/'}

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

2024-11-08 06:45:50,526: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is sleep important for overall health?

2024-11-08 06:45:50,526: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety

Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health

Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes,

2024-11-08 06:45:52,719: ObserveEventsHandler(  145): MEASUREMENT: Span: OpenAI.astream_chat-83a7a1e7-e661-48e1-b886-517289d95f87
2024-11-08 06:45:52,719: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:45:52,719: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is sleep important for overall health?

2024-11-08 06:45:52,719: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built

2024-11-08 06:45:52,970: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is sleep important for overall health?

2024-11-08 06:45:52,970: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

2024-11-08 06:45:53,168: ObserveEventsHandler(  145): MEASUREMENT: Span: OpenAI.astream_chat-83a7a1e7-e661-48e1-b886-517289d95f87
2024-11-08 06:45:53,168: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:45:53,168: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is sleep important for overall health?

2024-11-08 06:45:53,168: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. 2024-11-08 06:45:53,817: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is sleep important for overall health?

2024-11-08 06:45:53,818: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night

2024-11-08 06:45:54,008: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is sleep important for overall health?

2024-11-08 06:45:54,008: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep

2024-11-08 06:45:54,535: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health,

2024-11-08 06:45:54,729: ObserveEventsHandler(  145): MEASUREMENT: Span: OpenAI.astream_chat-83a7a1e7-e661-48e1-b886-517289d95f87
2024-11-08 06:45:54,729: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:45:54,729: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is sleep important for overall health?

2024-11-08 06:45:54,730: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease

As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. 2024-11-08 06:45:55,951: ObserveEventsHandler(  145): MEASUREMENT: Span: OpenAI.astream_chat-83a7a1e7-e661-48e1-b886-517289d95f87
2024-11-08 06:45:55,951: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:45:55,951: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is sleep important for overall health?

2024-11-08 06:45:55,951: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked

Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved

As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced

2024-11-08 06:45:56,773: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3

2024-11-08 06:45:57,278: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is sleep important for overall health?

2024-11-08 06:45:57,278: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3]. As Christopher E

2024-11-08 06:45:57,296: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3]. As Christopher E. Kline, Ph.D

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3]. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3]. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3]. As Christopher E. Kline, Ph.D., notes, "Focusing on obtaining

2024-11-08 06:45:57,686: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3]. 2024-11-08 06:45:57,688: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Sleep is essential for overall health, and research has consistently shown that it plays a critical role in maintaining physical and mental well-being. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3]. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), sleep is important for healthy brain function and physical health [6]. During sleep, the body performs various functions that support overall health, including the repair and regeneration of damaged cells, the building of bone and muscle, and the strengthening of the immune system [6]. Additionally, sleep helps to support the heart and circulatory system, with chronic sleep deprivation linked to an increased risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, obesity, and stroke [6].

Sleep is also crucial for cognitive function, with research showing that it aids in learning and forming long-term memories [6]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. In fact, one study found that older adults who get five or fewer hours of sleep per night are at risk for developing multiple chronic conditions, including mental health problems like anxiety and depression [2]. As Dr. Abhinav Singh, medical director of the Indiana Sleep Center, notes, "Quality sleep is the foundation on which optimal health is built. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3]. Furthermore, sleep has been shown to have a positive impact on mental health, with studies suggesting that it can help to reduce stress and anxiety [1]. Even if nutrition and exercise are at their best, without proper sleep, their benefits are greatly reduced" [4].

In terms of the amount of sleep needed, the CDC recommends that adults aim for seven to nine hours per night [2]. Research has shown that getting less than seven hours of sleep per night can have negative consequences for overall health, including an increased risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and stroke [3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3]. On the other hand, getting adequate sleep has been linked to a range of health benefits, including improved physical and mental health, better cognitive function, and a reduced risk of chronic diseases [1, 3].
